timeline.message:
Compile.hs: Generate code for type ascriptions.

Rust does not allow type ascriptions in arbitrary contexts; we therefore
used to skip type annotations, except in LHS of an assignment, relying on
Rust's type inference to do the work.  This does not work when expression
type cannot be inferred without explicit annotation, e.g.:

```
to_json_string(from_json_string(boolStruct1()): Result<BoolStruct, string>)
```

This commit implements a simple workaround: we compile `e: t` into
`{let __typed: t = e; t}`.

std.rs: (De)Serialize implementations for container types.

We used to auto-derive `Serialize` and `Deserialize` traits for `Vec`,
`Set`, and `Map`.  This automatic implementation wraps the inner
container type into additional struct (`std_Vec`, `std_Set`, `std_Map`).
This introduces unnecessary overhead and confuss JSON converter logic.

This commit replaces these with manual implementations of both traits that
simply forwards `serialize`/`deserialize` methods to the inner Rust type
(`Vec`, `BTreeSet`, `BTreeMap`).

`#[rust]` attribute for types, constructors, fields.

We introduce a new attribute that is passed directly to the Rust
compiler.  The value of the attribute is any valid attribute supported
by Rust for the same kind of entity.

This attribute is currently only supported for `typedef` declarations,
for individual constructors of types with multiple constructors, and
to constructor arguments.

For example, the following declaration:

```
typedef TaggedEnum = #[rust="serde(rename = \"t.V1\")"]
                     TVariant1 { b: bool }
                   | #[rust="serde(rename = \"t.V2\")"]
                     TVariant2 { u: u32 }
```

gets compiled to:

```
pub enum json_test_TaggedEnum {
    #[serde(rename = "t.V1")]
    json_test_TVariant1 {
        b: bool
    },
    #[serde(rename = "t.V2")]
    json_test_TVariant2 {
        u: std_u32
    }
}
```

timeline.message:
JSON serialization/deserialization library.

This library currently provides two functions to serialize/deserialize
JSON into DDlog types:

```
extern function from_json_string(json: string): Result<'T, string>
extern function to_json_string(x: 'T): Result<string, string>
```

It leverages the fact that all DDlog types implement `Serialize` and
`Deserialize` traits.  When combined with the `serde_json` crate, such
types become serializable to/from JSON.  The recently added `rust`
attribute can be used to configure serialization.

Example 1: Deserializing from a default format expected by `serde_json`:

Type declaration:

```
typedef BoolStruct = BoolStruct {
    b: bool
}
```

Valid JSON: `{"b":true}`

Example 2: Customizing JSON format:

Type declaration:

```
typedef TaggedEnum = #[rust="serde(rename = \"t.V1\")"]
                     TVariant1 { b: bool }
                   | #[rust="serde(rename = \"t.V2\")"]
                     TVariant2 { u: u32 }
```

Valid JSON: `{"@type": "t.V2", "u": 100}`

See https://serde.rs/attributes.html for documentation of
serialization-related attributes.

parse.rs: Import string literals from file.

When working with large strings, e.g., JSON files, it can be awkward and
error-prone to escape the string and insert it inline in a `.dat` file.
This commit implements new syntax to create a string literal equal to
the contents of a file: `%"path/to/file"`.

Example usage:

```
start;
insert JsonRelation[%"path/to/file.json"],
commit dump_changes;
```

json.dl: JsonScalarValue type.

Extend the `json.dl` library with an enum type that represents a scalar JSON
value whose type is not known in advance.  This requires a bit of Rust
magic to work as expected; therefore it makes sense to implement this as
a library type.
